{{Infobox officeholder | name = Earl Alexander Powell III | image = Members of the Commission of Fine Arts (U.S.) - February 2009.jpg | image_size = 250px | office = Chairman of the [[United States Commission of Fine Arts]] | term_start = 2005 | term_end = | predecessor = — | successor = | office1 = Director of the [[National Gallery of Art]] | term_start1 = September 1992 | term_end1 = | predecessor1 = — | successor1 = | caption = Earl A. Powell III (seated, center) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|10|24}} | birth_place = [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Museum director | spouse = Nancy Landry Powell<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/weddings/10powell.html Radomsky, Rosalie R. "Channing Powell, Jonathan Soverow." ''New York Times.'' October 8, 2010.] Accessed 2012-10-13.</ref> | parents = Earl Alexander Powell II and Elizabeth Duckworth Powell | children = }}
'''Earl Alexander Powell III''' (born October 24, 1943),<ref name="NGAPress">[http://www.nga.gov/press/bios/powell_cv.shtm "Earl A. Powell III." Online Press Kit. National Gallery of Art. 2012.] Accessed 2012-10-13.</ref> nicknamed '''Rusty Powell''', is an American [[Art history|art historian]] and museum director. From 1980 to 1992, he was Director of the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]]. He was appointed Director of the [[National Gallery of Art]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], in September 1992. He was appointed to the [[U.S. Commission of Fine Arts]] in 2003 and elected chairman in 2005. He was appointed to a second four-year term on August 30, 2012, and continues to serve as chairman.
==Early life== Earl Powell was born in October 1943 in [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]], to Earl Alexander Powell II and Elizabeth Duckworth Powell.<ref name="Dictionary">[http://www.dictionaryofarthistorians.org/powelle.htm "Powell, Earl [Alexander], III, 'Rusty'." Dictionary of Art Historians. No date.] Accessed 2012-10-13.</ref> His grandfather operated a [[photoengraving]] business, which Powell credits as influential in sparking his later love of art.<ref name="Tanguy">Tanguy, Sarah. "Glittering Conversation About the World of Art." ''Washington Times.'' March 30, 1994.</ref> The Powells moved to [[Rhode Island]]. "Rusty", as Powell was known, graduated from [[Providence Country Day School]] in 1962.<ref name="Siclen">Van Siclen, Bill. "Forging Another Link in the R.I. Art Connection." ''Providence Journal.'' May 10, 1992.</ref> He was a standout football player in high school.<ref>Wilson, William. "LACMA at a Turning Point." ''Los Angeles Times.'' August 5, 1992.</ref>
Powell graduated from [[Williams College]] in [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]] with a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[art history]] and [[European history]] (with honors) in 1966.<ref name="Dictionary" /><ref name="Siclen" /> He was a [[Pre-medical|pre-med]] major, but barely passed his introductory chemistry class.<ref name="Dob">Dobrzynski, Judith H. "An Art Lover Who Awakened a Generation." ''New York Times.'' October 28, 1997.</ref> Powell switched to art history, and studied under the legendary art history professors [[S. Lane Faison|S. Lane Faison, Jr.]],<ref name="Dob" /> [[Whitney Stoddard]],<ref>Johnson, Ken. "Whitney Stoddard, 90, Art Historian and Teacher." ''New York Times.'' April 14, 2003.</ref> and [[William Pierson, Jr.]]<ref>Grimes, William. "William H. Pierson Jr., 97, Art Historian." ''New York Times.'' December 12, 2008.</ref>
Powell enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] in 1966, winning a spot in the [[Officer Candidate School (U.S. Navy)|Navy Officer Candidate School]].<ref name="Siclen" /> His active duty service, which lasted until 1969,<ref name="Dictionary" /> included a tour of duty in [[Vietnam]] as a navigator during the Vietnam War.<ref name="Siclen" /> He left active duty service and entered the [[United States Navy Reserve]], serving until 1980.<ref name="Dictionary" /><ref name="Tanguy" />
After leaving the Navy, Powell considered becoming an architect. His old professor, S. Lane Faison, strongly discouraged him. As Powell later, recalled, Faison said, "That's stupid. You should go into art history. It's the only thing you were ever good at."<ref name="Dob" /> Powell enrolled at [[Harvard University]], where he obtained a [[Master of Arts]] from the [[Fogg Museum]] in 1970.<ref name="Dictionary" /> He entered the doctoral program in art history at Harvard in 1970. While working on his degree, he served as a [[teaching fellow]]. Powell's [[dissertation]] was on the work of the early American painter [[Thomas Cole]], and he received his doctorate in 19th-century American and European art history in 1974.<ref name="Dictionary" /><ref>Muchnic, Suzanne. "2 L.A. Museum Directors On National Gallery List." ''Los Angeles Times.'' April 2, 1992.</ref>
The same year he received his Ph.D., Powell took a position as assistant professor of art history at the [[University of Texas at Austin]].<ref name="ObamaAnnounces">"President Obama Announces More Key Administration Posts." Press release. Office of the President. The White House. August 16, 2012.</ref>
In 1976, Powell left the University of Texas to take a position as a curator at the National Gallery of Art (NGA).<ref name="ObamaAnnounces" /> The NGA's director at the time, [[J. Carter Brown]], recruited Powell away from teaching. "I first spotted (Powell) in Austin, Texas. It occurred to me that he had rare potential, someone who had a passion for art, but yet had his feet on the ground. He was a people person, yet he could also handle the administrative details...," Brown later said.<ref name="Marshall">Marshall, Matthew. "Bittersweet Time for Museum Head." ''Los Angeles Times.'' October 2, 1992.</ref> Powell stayed at the NGA for four years, rising to the position of executive curator in 1979.<ref>Richard, Paul. "The Big Shoes of J. Carter Brown." ''Washington Post.'' February 2, 1992; Richardson, Lynda. "Chronicle." ''New York Times.'' October 2, 1992.</ref> Brown later said, "Rusty was my right hand for years".<ref name="VogelAppoints">Vogel, Carol. "National Gallery Appoints Director to Succeed Brown." ''New York Times.'' April 29, 1992.</ref> During his time as curator, Powell organized some of the NGA's biggest exhibitions, including "The Splendor of Dresden: Five Centuries of Art Collecting" in 1978 and "American Light: The Luminist Movement" in 1980.<ref name="Siclen" />
==LACMA directorship== In January 1980, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) hired Powell to be its director.<ref>"Los Angeles Art Museum Names Its New Director." ''Christian Science Monitor.'' January 23, 1980.</ref>
Powell's tenure at LACMA was an outstanding one. In his first six years, he doubled the exhibition space by opening the Robert O. Anderson Building and the Pavilion for Japanese Art to house a rare collection of Japanese art.<ref>Cummings, Judith. "Cultural Boom Stirring in Southern California." ''New York Times.'' October 30, 1986.</ref> He also oversaw the opening of the museum's new outdoor [[sculpture garden]] in 1988.<ref>Muchnic, Suzanne. "LACMA Opens Sculpture Garden." ''Los Angeles Times.'' July 27, 1988.</ref>
Powell was also a successful fund-raiser for the museum. In his first eight years, he reached his fund-raising goal of $80 million.<ref>Voland, John. "Morning Report: First Off..." ''Los Angeles Times.'' July 21, 1988.</ref> In 1991, publisher [[Walter Annenberg]] donated $10 million to the museum, the largest cash donation in its history.<ref>Muchnic, Suzanne. "Annenberg to Give L.A. Art Museum $10 Million." ''Los Angeles Times.'' March 14, 1991.</ref> During Powell's tenure, the LACMA endowment also rose to $21 million from $3 million.<ref>Muchnic, Suzanne. "Art Museum Study Reveals Trouble in Raising Money." ''Los Angeles Times.'' July 30, 1993.</ref>
J. Carter Brown later described Powell's tenure as director of LACMA as one "bound for glory".<ref name="Marshall" />
==National Gallery of Art== On January 24, 1992, J. Carter Brown announced that he was retiring as director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C.<ref>Vogel, Carol. "Head of National Gallery Is Retiring." ''New York Times.'' January 25, 1992.</ref> After a nationwide search, Earl A. Powell III was named director of the National Gallery of Art. He was only the fourth director in the museum's history.<ref name="VogelAppoints" /> He assumed the directorship on September 1, 1992.<ref>Vogel, Carol. "The Art Market." ''New York Times.'' June 19, 1992.</ref> When he was appointed, Powell said that he believed the era of "blockbuster" exhibitions was ending, and that his focus would be to utilize the NGA's permanent collection. "I don't see the future for these massive international loan exhibitions," he said. "I would prefer to use the gallery's permanent collections in new and innovative ways."<ref name="VogelAppoints" />
[[File:The Holy Family on the Steps.jpg|thumb|''The Holy Family on the Steps'', which the NGA learned during Powell's tenure was not by Nicolas Poussin.]] During the beginning of Powell's tenure at the NGA, he faced several challenges. In May 1994, the NGA learned that its painting, ''The Holy Family on the Steps'', was a forgery and not the work of 17th-century French painter [[Nicolas Poussin]]. Powell was criticized for not ordering the relabeling of the painting in a timely manner, and for mishandling the NGA's response to its critics.<ref>"Truth in Labeling." ''Washington Post.'' November 13, 1994.</ref> In December 1994, D.C. television station [[WJLA-TV|WJLA]] ran a three-part exposé titled "Gallery of Shame", in which the station revealed the content of a confidential report that criticized the NGA for severe lapses in maintenance, environmental control, and art storage. The report said that these conditions "threaten[ed] the security of the collection" and placed works of art "at risk" of "serious damage."<ref name="Lewis">Lewis, Jo Ann. "Gallery Weathers the Storm." ''Washington Post.'' December 3, 1994.</ref><ref name="VogelShame">Vogel, Carol. "Inside Art." ''New York Times.'' December 9, 1994.</ref> The report documented a leaky roof, dripping skylights, flooded storerooms, and burst radiators that poured clouds of steam into galleries. In one case, a poorly maintained [[humidifier]] turned the varnish on [[John Singleton Copley]]'s ''[[Watson and the Shark]]'' an opaque white.<ref name="Lewis" /><ref name="VogelShame" /> (The painting was restored with no damage.) The report also criticized the management structure at the museum, documented low employee morale, and uncovered poor minority hiring practices.<ref name="Lewis" /> Powell attacked WJLA's report as "hyperbole and exaggeration", and said that not a single work of art had been damaged.<ref name="VogelShame" /> He also said that the NGA had been aware of the problems for several years,<ref name="VogelShame" /> and that he already had a plan in place to implement the consultants' recommendations within 12 months.<ref name="Lewis" />
Powell has also had numerous and notable successes as NGA director. In 1995, the museum mounted the first comprehensive retrospective of the work of American painter [[Winslow Homer]] in 25 years. It also hosted an exhibit of nearly all the works of 17th century [[Netherlands|Dutch]] painter [[Johannes Vermeer]]. The Vermeer exhibit was shuttered three times in November and December 1995 when the [[United States federal government shutdown of 1995 and 1996|federal government shut down]] after President [[Bill Clinton]] and the [[United States Congress]] were unable to reach agreement on a federal budget.<ref>Weinraub, Judith. "A Bleak Picture of the Shutdown." ''Washington Post.'' December 22, 1995.</ref> Powell ordered that $30,000 from the NGA's Fund for International Exchange be used to reopen the Vermeer exhibit (but no other parts of the National Gallery of Art) for one week.<ref>Lewis, Jo Ann and Parker, Lonnae O'Neal. "A Dutch Treat: Vermeer Show to Reopen." ''Washington Post.'' December 27, 1995.</ref> In 1997, Powell presided over the ground-breaking for the [[National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden]].<ref>Hartman, Carl. "Sculpture Garden to Surround Skating Rink on Washington's Mall." ''Associated Press.'' June 13, 1997; Shaw-Eagle, Joanna. "National Gallery Breaks Ground for Sculpture Garden." ''Washington Times.'' June 13, 1997.</ref>
==Other posts, writing, and honors== In June 2002, President [[George W. Bush]] nominated and the [[United States Senate]] approved Powell for a position as a member of the National Council on the Arts, an advisory panel for the [[National Endowment for the Arts]]. Powell filled an unexpired six-year term which would end on September 3, 2006.<ref>Dutka, Elaine. "Arts and Entertainment Reports." ''Los Angeles Times.'' June 14, 2002; Donadio, Rachel. "In Brief." ''New York Sun.'' April 11, 2003.</ref> But Powell resigned the position in late 2003.<ref>"Personnel Announcement." Press release. Office of the President. The White House. January 7, 2004.</ref>
In May 2005, architect [[David Childs]] resigned as chairman of the [[U.S. Commission of Fine Arts]] (CFA).<ref>Thomas E. Luebke, ed., ''Civic Art: A Centennial History of the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts'' (Washington, D.C.: U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, 2013): Appendix B, p. 552.</ref> President Bush immediately appointed Powell to the commission.<ref>Forgey, Benjamin. "Childs Resigns as Head of Fine Arts Panel." ''Washington Post.'' May 21, 2005.</ref> His fellow commissioners elected Powell chairman of the CFA. During his tenure as chairman of the CFA, Powell and the CFA provided input and advice for the ''Monumental Core Framework Plan'', a 2006 study by the [[National Capital Planning Commission]] which made recommendations regarding land use, transportation, and urban design in areas around the [[National Mall]].<ref>Wagner, Arlo. "Planners See Ideas Beyond the Mall." ''Washington Times.'' May 18, 2006.</ref> President Bush reappointed Powell to the CFA in May 2008.<ref>Ruane, Michael E. "District Briefing." ''Washington Post.'' May 10, 2008.</ref> Again he was elected chairman. During his second term, Powell led the CFA in participating in the study and review of the ''Final National Mall Plan / Environmental Impact Statement''—a 2010 plan by the [[National Park Service]] to craft a vision and planning document to guide the [[National Mall]] in Washington, D.C., for the next 50 years.<ref>Ruane, Michael E. "Fine-Arts Panel Enthusiastic About Plan to Overhaul the Mall." ''Washington Post.'' February 19, 2010.</ref>
President [[Barack Obama]] appointed Powell to a second full four-year term on the CFA in August 2012.<ref name="ObamaAnnounces" /> Once more, Powell continued as chairman.
===Written works=== Powell has published a number of scholarly and popular works. As curator and director at two major art museums, he has written numerous exhibit reviews and introductions to exhibit catalogs. Among the more notable of these is his 1980 essay on early American [[Luminism (American art style)|Luminist]] painter [[Fitz Henry Lane|Fitz Hugh Lane]].<ref>Richard, Paul. "Shipshape Mysteries On Canvas." ''Washington Post.'' May 15, 1988; Casey, Edward S. ''Representing Place: Landscape Painting and Maps.'' Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2002, p. 283 fn.16.</ref>
As a scholar of the works of Thomas Cole, Powell has written extensively on the painter's art. His more prominent works include "Thomas Cole's 'Dream of Arcadia'" (published in ''[[Arts Magazine]]'' in November 1977),<ref>Wilmerding, John; Ayres, Linda; Powell, Earl A.; and Ganz, Julian. ''An American Perspective: Nineteenth-Century Art From the collection of Jo Ann & Julian Ganz, Jr.'' Washington, D.C.: National Gallery of Art, 1981, p. 123.</ref> and "Thomas Cole and the American Landscape Tradition: The Naturalist Controversy" (published in ''Arts Magazine'' in February 1978).<ref>Rosenbaum, Julia B. ''Visions of Belonging: New England Art and the Making of American Identity.'' Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 2006, p. 183 fn. 4.</ref> Powell also authored a monograph on Thomas Cole in 1990.<ref>Wilson, William. "Watching LACMA Grow." ''Los Angeles Times.'' October 21, 1990; Russell, John. "Art." ''New York Times.'' December 2, 1990.</ref> A revised second edition was published in 2000.<ref>Armstrong, Robert. "A Galaxy of Stellar Picture Books in Time for the Holidays." ''Minneapolis Star Tribune.'' November 26, 2000.</ref>
===Honors=== Powell has been honored with several positions. He was elected to a three-year term on the [[Pitzer College]] Board of Trustees in 1986,<ref name="People">"People." ''Los Angeles Times.'' February 13, 1986.</ref> and was a director of the [[Georgia O'Keeffe Foundation]] in 2005.<ref>Oswald, Mark. "O'Keeffe Museum to Gain Pieces." ''Albuquerque Journal.'' June 1, 2005.</ref>
Powell has also been awarded honorary doctorates from the [[Otis College of Art and Design]] (1987)<ref name="NGAPress" /> and Williams College (1993).<ref>"Williams Honors Jim Lehrer." ''New York Times.'' June 5, 1993.</ref>
Among the many awards Powell has received are the [[St. Olav's Medal]] from [[Norway]] (1978), the [[Order of Prince Henry]] from [[Portugal]] (1995), the [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic]] from [[Italy]] (1998), Knight of the [[Legion of Honour]] from [[France]] (2000), Officer of the [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] from France (2004), [[Order of the Aztec Eagle]] from [[Mexico]] (2007), and the Officer's Cross of the [[Order of Merit of the Republic of Hungary]] (2009).<ref name="NGAPress" />
==Personal life== Earl Powell married Nancy Landry of [[New Orleans]] in 1971.<ref name="Dictionary" /> They have three children.<ref name="NGAPress" />
The Powells owned a summer home in [[Newport, Rhode Island]], where (as of 1992) Powell's mother and mother-in-law both lived.<ref name="Siclen" />

'''ISAE 3402''' is an [[Assurance services|assurance standard]]. The title is "Assurance Reports on Controls at a Service Organization". It was published in June 2011 as a standard for documenting that a service organisation has adequate [[internal controls]]; the approach is always from a financial reporting perspective,<ref>{{cite web|title=Third party assurance (e.g. ISAE 3402)|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/be/en/pages/risk/solutions/third-party-assurance.html|publisher=Deloitte|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ISAE 3402 Type II Service Organization Control - SOC Reporting|url=http://www.rackspace.co.uk/certifications/isae-3402-type-ii-service-organization-control-soc2-reporting|publisher=Rackspace|accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref>for all other purposes one would use a ISAE 3000. In SOC terms, an ISAE 3402 is a SOC1. ISAE stands for "International Standard for Assurance Engagements".
Like [[SAS 70]] and [[SSAE 16]], ISAE 3402 prescribes Service Organization Control reports, which help give assurance to the organisation's customers and service users, who may have their own assurance needs.<ref>{{cite web|title=ISAE 3402 Services|url=https://a-lign.com/compliance/isae-3402/|publisher=A-LIGN|accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> There are two kinds of ISAE 3402 reports: * Type I: Documenting a "snapshot" of the organisation's controls * Type II: Documenting over a period of time (typically 6 months) showing controls have been managed over time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Service organization control (SOC) reports|url=http://isae3402.com/ISAE3402_reports.html|publisher=isae3402.com|accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref>
ISAE 3402 was developed by the [[IAASB]] ([[International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board]]), but it is also supported by the IFAC ([[International Federation of Accountants]]). It supersedes [[SAS 70]],<ref>{{cite web|title=ISAE 3402|url=https://www.unicc.org/Pages/OurAdvantages/ISAE3402.aspx|publisher=ICC|accessdate=9 May 2018}}</ref> and puts more emphasis on procedures for the ongoing monitoring and evaluation of controls.
==See also== * [[ISAE 3000]] * [[Sarbanes–Oxley Act]] * [[SAS 70]] * [[SSAE 16]]
==External links== * [[Deloitte]], [https://www2.deloitte.com/be/en/pages/risk/solutions/third-party-assurance.html What is ISAE 3402?] * [http://www.ifac.org/system/files/downloads/b014-2010-iaasb-handbook-isae-3402.pdf ISAE 3402] * [[Ernst and Young]], [http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/Broszura_EY_ISAE_3402/$FILE/ISAE_3402.pdf Implementing and maintaining ISAE 3402] *[http://www.isae3402.co.uk International ISAE3402 register] *[http://www.risklane.nl/isae-3402 ISAE 3402 library (Dutch)] *[http://www.isae3402.nl ISAE3402 register (Netherlands)] *[http://isae3402.conclude.nl ISAE3402 information (Dutch)]

{{Infobox book | name = Kafka's Soup | image = Kafka's Soup.jpg | author = [[Mark Crick]] | illustrator = Mark Crick | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = | genre = Cookery/Pastiche | publisher = [[Libri Publications|Libri]] | pub_date = 2005 | media_type = | pages = 96 | isbn = 978-1-901965-09-4 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | followed_by = [[Sartre's Sink]] }} '''''Kafka's Soup''''' is a literary [[Genre parodies|pastiche]] in the form of a [[cookbook]].<ref name=Paris/> It contains 14 recipes<ref name=Note/> each written in the style of a famous author from history. As of 2007 it had been translated into 18 languages<ref name=Paris/> and published in 27 countries.<ref name=Age/> Excerpts from the book have appeared in the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]''<ref name=Herald/> and the ''[[New York Times]]''.<ref name=NewYork/> Theatrical performances of the recipes have taken place in France and Canada.
==Recipes== Recipes include: [[tiramisu]] as made by [[Proust]],<ref name=Age/><ref name=Marianne/><ref name=Independent1/> [[cheese on toast]] by [[Harold Pinter]],<ref name=Herald/><ref name=Independent1/><ref name=Observer/> [[clafoutis]] grandmere by [[Virginia Woolf]],<ref name=Herald/><ref name=Telegraph1/> [[chocolate cake]] prepared by [[Irvine Welsh]],<ref name=Independent1/><ref name=Observer/><ref name=Telegraph1/> lamb with dill sauce by [[Raymond Chandler]],<ref name=Observer/><ref name=Telegraph1/> onion tart by [[Chaucer]],<ref name=Age/><ref name=Independent1/><ref name=Telegraph1/> [[fenkata]] ([[rabbit stew]]) by [[Homer]],<ref name=Age/><ref name=Independent1/> boned stuffed [[Poussin (chicken)|poussins]] by the [[Marquis de Sade]],<ref name=Marianne/><ref name=Independent1/><ref name=Telegraph1/> mushroom [[risotto]] by [[John Steinbeck]],<ref name=Independent1/><ref name=Telegraph1/> tarragon eggs by [[Jane Austen]],<ref name=Age/><ref name=Independent1/> Vietnamese chicken by [[Graham Greene]]<ref name=Independent1/> and [[Kafka]]'s [[Miso soup]].<ref name=Age/><ref name=Marianne/><ref name=Telegraph1/> Also included are recipes in the style of [[Jorge Luis Borges]] and [[Gabriel García Márquez]].<ref name=Independent1/>
Among the recipes that did not make the original edition of the book was "[[plum pudding]] à la [[Charles Dickens]]" which was written but rejected by Mark Crick for being "too long-winded".<ref name=Telegraph1/> It was, however, included in a subsequent paperback edition of the book<ref name=Age/> along with two recipes, [[Rösti]] à la [[Thomas Mann]] and [[moules marinieres]] à la [[Italo Calvino]], originally created for the German and Italian translations respectively.<ref name=Paris/>
''Kafka's Soup'' is illustrated with paintings by the author in the style of a number of famous artists including [[Picasso]], [[Matisse]], [[William Hogarth|Hogarth]], [[De Chirico]], [[Henry Moore]], [[Egon Schiele]] and [[Warhol]].<ref name=Paris/><ref name=Independent1/><ref name=Telegraph1/>
''Kafka's Soup'' is Mark Crick's first book.<ref name=Age/> He has subsequently written two other books with similar themes; ''[[Sartre's Sink]]'' and ''Machiavelli's Lawn'' which are literary pastiches in the form of a DIY handbook and a gardening book respectively.<ref name=FT/><ref name=BBC/>
==Writing ''Kafka's Soup''== The idea for ''Kafka's Soup'' arose during a conversation between Crick and a publisher.<ref name=Age/> Crick noted his dislike for cookbooks<ref name=Telegraph1/> saying that he enjoyed looking at the pictures but found the accompanying text dull.<ref name=Age/> When asked what would it take for him to read beyond the ingredients list he replied "if [the text] was written by the world's greatest authors."<ref name=Age/> The publisher liked the idea and, in Crick's words, "she said that if I wrote it she'd publish it."<ref name=Age/>
Most of the recipes in the book are Crick's own, although some, such as the chocolate cake, came from his friends.<ref name=Publishers/> Crick notes the implausibility of some of his authors cooking their stated dishes (for example he states that John Steinbeck "would never have eaten [mushroom risotto]"<ref name=Telegraph1/> and "I certainly accept any challenge that Kafka would not have eaten miso soup"<ref name=Publishers/>). He says that he selected the recipes based on the ability of each dish to allow him to use the language he wished to use.<ref name=Publishers/> Chocolate cake was selected for Irvine Welsh because "people become terribly selfish when there's chocolate cake around, just as they do with drugs. It's the closest many get to taking heroin."<ref name=Telegraph1/>
Crick says that he found Virginia Woolf the most difficult of the authors to write<ref name=Telegraph1/> while Raymond Chandler was the easiest.<ref name=Surrey/>
==Response== ''Kafka's Soup'' has become a cult hit.<ref name=Paris/> Andy Miller of the ''Telegraph'' called the recipes "note-perfect parodies of literary greats".<ref name=Telegraph2/> Emily Stokes of the ''Observer'' called it an "illustrated masterpiece of pastiche" citing the lamb with dill sauce as "particularly good".<ref name=Observer/> C J Schüler wrote that Virginia Woolf's clafoutis grandmere is the "pièce de resistance" and called the collection "irresistibly moreish".<ref name=Independent1/> He later called the book "a little gem of literary impersonation".<ref name=Paris/> Schüler believes that "part of the book's appeal lies in the fact that the recipes...actually work."<ref name=Paris/> The French writer and satirist [[Patrick Rambaud]] has named ''Kafka's soup'' as one of his favourite parodies, noting the inclusion of parodies of continental European authors such as Proust and the Marquis de Sade in addition to English-speaking authors.<ref name=Marianne/>Some have noticed the similarity with the story written by Frederic Grimani Fiegenwald Coy, one year earlier: https://storywrite.com/story/7598601-what-would-franz-kafka-say-if-you-knock-on-his-toilet-door--by-sexy
==Translations== As of 2007 ''Kafka's Soup'' had been translated into 18 languages<ref name=Paris/> and published in 27 countries.<ref name=Age/> The Croatian translation proved more popular than ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'', forcing it in to second place on the country's best seller list.<ref name=Paris/> Each recipe in the French version was translated by a separate translator specialising in the translation of the works of the parodied author.<ref name=Paris/>
==Theatrical readings== In England, the recipes have reportedly been used as audition pieces by a small [[West Country]] theatre company.<ref name=Paris/> The [[Théâtre de l'Atelier]] in Paris hosted a performance of the French translation of the book in 2007. The production included performances by [[Irène Jacob]], [[Isabelle Carré]] and [[Denis Podalydès]], including a sung version of the recipe for onion tart.<ref name=Paris/> A live reading of the French translation of ''Kafka's Soup'' took place at the Montreal [[Festival International de la Littérature]] in 2007 with the author in attendance.<ref name=Montreal/> The production received an additional performance run in the [[Terrebonne, Quebec|Terrebonne]] suburb of Montreal in 2009.<ref name=Voir/>

{{Infobox website | name = Klexikon | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = <!-- or: | logocaption = --> | screenshot = | collapsible = <!-- set as "on", "y", etc, otherwise omit/leave blank --> | collapsetext = <!-- collapsible area's heading (default "Screenshot"); omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = | screenshot_alt = | caption = Klexikon | url = {{URL|klexikon.zum.de}} | slogan = | commercial = No | type = Encyclopedia | registration = Mandatory | language = German | num_users = | content_license = [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons By Attribution Share-alike v. 3.0]] | programming_language = [[Media Wiki]] | owner = Zentrale für Unterrichtsmedien im Internet | author = <!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = <!-- or: | editors = --> | launch_date ={{start date and age|2014|12|df=yes}} | revenue = | alexa = <!-- {{increase}} {{steady}} {{decrease}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/example.com ##] (US/Global MM/YYYY) --> | ip = | issn = <!-- ISSN, e.g. 1085-6706 (automatically linked to http://www.WorldCat.org) --> | oclc = <!-- OCLC number, useful where an ISSN has not been allocated (automatically linked to http://www.WorldCat.org) --> | current_status = | footnotes = }} [[File:2017 klexikon lesezeichen.jpg|thumb|The Klexikon logo displays an owl as a symbol of wisdom and knowledge.]]
'''Klexikon''' is a German online encyclopedia for children aged six to twelve years. It was launched in December 2014. The name ''Klexikon'' is a [[portmanteau]] combining the two German words ''Kinder'' [children] and ''Lexikon'' [encyclopedia] Like its role model Wikipedia, the site was created as a [[wiki]] using the [[MediaWiki]] software. The text content is available under a [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons By Attribution Share-alike]] version 3.0 licence while free media is taken from [[Wikimedia Commons]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://klexikon.zum.de/wiki/Hilfe:In_English |title=In English |work=Klexikon |date=5 July 2017 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://klexikon.zum.de/wiki/Hilfe:Freies_Wissen |title=Freies Wissen |language=German |work=Klexikon |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> Special rules were implemented to ensure that all content is suitable for children.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://klexikon.zum.de/wiki/Hilfe:Grundregeln |title=Grundregeln |language=German |work=Klexikon |date=22 July 2017 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> Moreover, all editors are required to register with an email address.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://klexikon.zum.de/wiki/Hilfe:Mitmachen |title=Grundregeln |language=German |work=Klexikon |date=22 July 2017 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
==History== The Klexikon encyclopedia was founded by journalist Michael Schulte and historian Ziko van Dijk, who was the chairman of [[Wikimedia Nederland|Wikimedia Netherlands]] from 2011 to 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.geo.de/geolino/mensch/1175-rtkl-interview-klexikonde-wikipedia-fuer-kinder |title=Klexikon.de - Wikipedia für Kinder |language=German |work=[[GEO (magazine)|GEOlino]] |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> The website is owned by non-profit association ''Zentrale für Unterrichtsmedien im Internet'' [online educational media centre] which also hosts other types of Wikis.
One year after its launch, Klexikon consisted of 1,000 articles and 1,500 articles had been created after two years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.zeit.de/2015/47/klexikon-internet-kinder-lexikon |title=Wikipedia für Kinder: Wo bleibt der Pups? |language=German |first=Johanna |last=Schoener |work=[[Die Zeit]] |date=14 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://klexikon.zum.de/wiki/Hilfe:Daten_zum_Klexikon |title=Daten zum Klexikon |language=German |work=Klexikon |date=19 August 2017 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> The Klexikon community of editors decides per consensus which articles should be created next so as to assure that the most important topics, school subjects and areas of interest of children are covered.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://klexikon.zum.de/wiki/Hilfe:Artikelw%C3%BCnsche |title=Artikelwünsche |language=German |work=Klexikon |date=12 September 2017 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
Klexikon was supported by [[Wikimedia Deutschland|Wikimedia Germany]] in creating the concept of an online encyclopedia for children.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blog.wikimedia.org/2015/07/15/klexikon-encyclopedia-for-children/ |title=The Klexikon: a new wiki encyclopedia for children |work=[[Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia BLog]] |date=15 July 2015 |first=Ed |last=Erhart |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> The concept was then refined by cooperating with [[Technical University of Dortmund]] and [[Technical University of Cologne]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.studiger.tu-dortmund.de/images/Ank%C3%BCndigung_Klexikon.pdf |title=klexikon.de: Auf dem Weg zu einer Wikipedia für Kinder – Möglichkeiten für den Deutschunterricht |language=German |publisher=[[Technical University of Dortmund]] |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.th-koeln.de/hochschule/projekt-klexikon_21748.php |title=Projekt 'Klexikon' |language=German |first=Mirka |last=Dickmann |publisher=[[Technical University of Cologne]] |editor-first=Ute Barbara |editor-last=Schilly |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== The German [[Federal Ministry of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth]] considers the site a "useful" children's encyclopedia.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bmfsfj.de/blob/96218/584a19f47509dba7282aa41091959d57/ein-netz-fuer-kinder-gutes-aufwachsen-mit-medien-data.pdf |title=Gutes Aufwachen mit Medien. Ein Netz für Kinder |publisher=[[Federal Ministry of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth]] |language=German |page=9}}</ref> According to the voluntary self control associtation of German television, Klexikon's advantage is that unlike Wikipedia it is specifically written for children.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.fsf.de/digitale-welt/klexikon-de/2016/07 |title=Klexikon.de: Wenn Wissen mitmachen lässt. |language=German |publisher=Freiwillige Selbstkontrolle Fernsehen}}</ref> The Austrian School Portal wrote that Klexikon was a "great work of reference" which provided content that was speficically balanced for children.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.schule.at/news/detail/wikipedia-fuer-kinder.html |title=Wikipedia für Kinder |language=German |first=Sabrina |last=Mayrhofer |publisher=Österreichisches Schulportal |date=15 June 2016 |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> The ''Merz'' magazine noted that Klexikon was an online source of information with relatively reliable content, but criticised that articles did not provide any sources. This was contrary to the need of sensitising school children for marking secondary information as such.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.merz-zeitschrift.de/?NAV_ID=11&HEFT_ID=149&RECORD_ID=7026 |title=Klexikon: Eine Wikipedia für Kinder |first=Katrin |last=Fleischmann |language=German |issue=4 |year=2015 |work=Merz – Medien + Erziehung}}</ref>
==Awards and nominations== * 2015: ''Pädi – der pädagogische Interaktiv-Preis'' [The Pedagogical Interactive Prize]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.studioimnetz.de/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Pädi-Preisträger-2015.pdf |title=PÄDI – der Pädagogische Interaktiv-Preis 2015 |language=German |page=2 |publisher=SIN - Studio im Netz e.V.}}</ref> * 2016: Nominated for the 2016 [[Open educational resources]] award in the category "educational fusion"<ref>{{cite web |title=OER-Award 2016 – Wettbewerb und oer.academy |language=German |work=OERinfo – open-educational-resources.de |url=http://open-educational-resources.de/16/award/ |accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>

{{Other uses}} {{automatic taxobox | name = Marlin |image =Atlantic blue marlin.jpg | image_caption = [[Atlantic blue marlin]] ''(Makaira nigricans)'' | image_width = | taxon = Istiophoridae | authority = [[Constantine Samuel Rafinesque|Rafinesque]], 1810 | subdivision_ranks = Genera | subdivision = * ''[[Black marlin|Istiompax]]'' * ''[[Sailfish|Istiophorus]]'' * ''[[Kajikia]]'' * ''[[Makaira]]'' * ''[[Tetrapturus]]'' }} A '''marlin''' is a fish from the family '''Istiophoridae''', which includes about 10 species. It has an elongated body, a [[spear]]-like [[snout]] or bill, and a long, rigid [[dorsal fin]] which extends forward to form a crest. Its [[common name]] is thought to derive from its resemblance to a sailor's [[marlinspike]].<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=marlin | title = marlin | work = Online Etymological Dictionary | author = Douglas Harper |date=November 2001 }}</ref> Even more so than their close relatives, the [[scombrid]]s, marlins are fast swimmers, reaching speeds of about {{convert|80|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref name=EoF> {{cite book |editor=Paxton, J. R. |editor2=Eschmeyer, W. N. |author1=Johnson, G .D. |author2=Gill, A. C. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1998 |title=Encyclopedia of Fishes |publisher= Academic Press |location=San Diego |pages= 190–191 |isbn= 0-12-547665-5 }}</ref>
The larger species include the [[Atlantic blue marlin]], ''Makaira nigricans'', which can reach {{convert|5|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} in length and {{convert|818|kg|lb|abbr=on}} in weight<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fishbase.org/summary/Makaira-nigricans.html|title=Makaira nigricans, Blue marlin : fisheries, gamefish|work=FishBase}}</ref> and the [[black marlin]], ''Istiompax indica'', which can reach in excess of {{convert|5|m|ft|1|abbr=on}} in length and {{convert|670|kg|lb|abbr=on}} in weight. They are popular [[sport fishing|sporting fish]] in tropical areas.<!-- encyclopedic? Many sporting fishers like to try their luck at catching a massive marlin.-->
==Classification== The marlins are [[perciformes|perciform]] fish, most closely related to the [[swordfish]] and [[Scombridae]].

==In literature== [[File:Welcome to Dare County marlin - Stierch.jpg|thumbnail|A [[taxidermy]] marlin greets visitors to [[Dare County, North Carolina]].]] In the [[Nobel Prize]]-winning author [[Ernest Hemingway|Ernest Hemingway's]] 1952 novel ''[[The Old Man and the Sea]]'', the central character of the work is an aged Cuban fisherman who, after 84 days without success on the water, heads out to sea to break his run of bad luck. On the 85th day, Santiago, the old fisherman, hooks a resolute marlin; what follows is a great struggle between man, sea creature, and the elements.
[[Frederick Forsyth]]'s story "The Emperor", in the collection ''[[No Comebacks]]'', tells of a bank manager named Murgatroyd, who catches a marlin and is acknowledged by the islanders of [[Mauritius]] as a master fisherman.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = J. Pierpont Morgan Library | nrhp_type=nhl | image = Pierpont Morgan Library NY 2006 crop.jpg | image_size = 325px | caption = (2006) | location = 225 [[Madison Avenue]]
at [[36th Street (Manhattan)|East 36th Street]]
[[Manhattan]], [[New York City]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|44|55.69|N|73|58|53.6|W|display=title}} | locmapin = United States Manhattan#New York#USA | map_label =Morgan Library & Museum | area = | built = 1900–06 | architect = [[Charles Follen McKim]]{{cite aia5}}, p.281 | architecture = [[Palladian]] | designated_nrhp_type= November 13, 1966{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=391&ResourceType=Building|title=J. Pierpont Morgan Library|date=September 18, 2007|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010134231/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=391&ResourceType=Building|archivedate=October 10, 2012|df=mdy-all}} | added = November 13, 1966 | governing_body = Private | refnum = 66000544{{NRISref|version=2010a}} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | website = [http://www.themorgan.org/ TheMorgan.org] | designated_other2_name = NYC Landmark | designated_other2_date = May 17, 1966 | designated_other2_abbr = NYCL | designated_other2_link = New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission | designated_other2_number = | designated_other2_color = #ffe978 }} The '''Morgan Library & Museum''' – formerly the '''Pierpont Morgan Library''' – is a museum and research library located at 225 [[Madison Avenue]] at [[36th Street (Manhattan)|East 36th Street]] in the [[Murray Hill, Manhattan|Murray Hill]] neighborhood of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. It was founded to house the private library of [[J. P. Morgan]] in 1906, which included manuscripts and printed books, some of them in rare bindings, as well as his collection of prints and drawings. The library was designed by [[Charles Follen McKim|Charles McKim]] of the firm of [[McKim, Mead and White]] and cost $1.2 million. It was made a public institution in 1924 by J. P. Morgan's son [[J. P. Morgan, Jr.|John Pierpont Morgan, Jr.]], in accordance with his father's will. The building was designated a [[List of New York City Landmarks|New York City landmark]] in 1966{{cite nycland}}, p.98 and was declared a [[National Historic Landmark]] later that same year.{{cite web|last=Greenwood|first=Richard|url={{NHLS url|id=66000544}}|title="The Pierpont Morgan Library", National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination|date=July 18, 1975|publisher=National Park Service}}{{cite web|url={{NHLS url|id=66000544|photos=y}}|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination|date=July 18, 1975|publisher=National Park Service}} == Collection == {{Main category|Collection of the Morgan Library & Museum}} Today the library is a complex of buildings which serve as a museum and scholarly research center. The scope of the collection was shaped in its early years as a private collection by [[Belle da Costa Greene]], J.P. Morgan's personal librarian, who became the library's first director and served from the time that it became public until her retirement in 1948. Her successor [[Frederick Baldwin Adams, Jr.]] managed the Library until 1969 and was also world-renowned for his own personal collections. The most internationally significant part of the collection is its relatively small but very select collection of [[illuminated manuscript]]s, and medieval artworks such as the [[Stavelot Triptych]] and the metalwork covers of the [[Lindau Gospels]]. Among the more famous manuscripts are the [[Morgan Bible]], [[Morgan Beatus]], [[Hours of Catherine of Cleves]], [[Farnese Hours]], [[Black Hours, Morgan MS 493|Morgan Black Hours]], and [[Codex Glazier]]. The [[manuscript]] collection also includes authors' original manuscripts, including some by Sir [[Walter Scott]] and [[Honoré de Balzac]], as well as the scraps of paper on which [[Bob Dylan]] jotted down "[[Blowin' in the Wind]]" and "[[It Ain't Me Babe]]". It also contains a large collection of [[incunabula]], prints, and drawings of European artists—[[Leonardo da Vinci|Leonardo]], [[Michelangelo]], [[Raphael]], [[Rembrandt]], [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]], [[Thomas Gainsborough|Gainsborough]], [[Dürer]], and [[Picasso]]; early printed [[Bible]]s, among them three [[Gutenberg Bible]]s; and many examples of fine [[bookbinding]]. Other holdings include material from ancient Egypt and medieval liturgical objects (including [[Coptic literature]] examples),{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/16027d.htm |title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Coptic Literature |publisher=Newadvent.org |date=March 1, 1914 |accessdate=2012-06-18}} [[Émile Zola]], [[William Blake|William Blake's]] original drawings for [[William Blake's Illustrations of the Book of Job|his edition]] of the ''Book of Job''; concept drawings for ''[[The Little Prince]]'' by [[Antoine de Saint-Exupéry]]; a [[Percy Bysshe Shelley]] notebook; originals of poems by [[Robert Burns]]; a unique [[Charles Dickens]] manuscript of ''A Christmas Carol'' with handwritten edits and markup from the author; a journal by [[Henry David Thoreau]]; an extraordinary collection of autographed and annotated libretti and scores from Beethoven, Brahms, Chopin, Mahler and Verdi, and [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart's]] Haffner Symphony in D Major; and manuscripts of [[George Sand]], [[William Makepeace Thackeray]], [[Lord Byron]], [[Charlotte Brontë]] and nine of [[Sir Walter Scott|Sir Walter Scott's]] novels, including ''Ivanhoe''. The collection still includes a few [[Old Master]] paintings collected by Morgan between 1907 and 1911 (works by [[Hans Memling]], [[Perugino]], and [[Cima da Conegliano]]), but this has never been the collection's focus, and [[Domenico Ghirlandaio|Ghirlandaio]]'s masterpiece ''Portrait of Giovanna Tornabuoni'' was sold to [[Heinrich, Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza de Kászon|Thyssen]] when the Great Depression worsened the Morgan family's finances.Kandell, Jonathan. [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/28/nyregion/baron-thyssen-bornemisza-industrialist-who-built-fabled-art-collection-dies-81.html?pagewanted=all "Baron Thyssen-Bornemisza, Industrialist Who Built Fabled Art Collection, Dies at 81,"] New York ''Times'', April 28, 2002. Other notable artists of the Morgan Library and Museum are [[Jean de Brunhoff]], [[Paul Cézanne]], [[Vincent van Gogh]], [[John Leech (caricaturist)|John Leech]], [[Gaston Phoebus]], [[Rembrandt van Rijn]], and [[John Ruskin]].{{Cite journal | title=The Morgan Library & Museum: About | publisher=ARTINFO | year=2008 | url=http://www.artinfo.com/galleryguide/22151/8669/about/the-morgan-library-and-museum-new-york/ | accessdate=July 30, 2008 | postscript= }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Morgan has one of the world's greatest collections of ancient Near Eastern [[cylinder seals]], small stone cylinders finely engraved with images for transfer to clay by rolling.{{cite web|url=http://www.themorgan.org/collections/collectionsSeals.asp |title=Overview of Morgan seal collection |publisher=Themorgan.org |date= |accessdate=2012-06-18}} It also contains many music manuscripts and a considerable collection of Victoriana, including one of the most important collections of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] manuscripts and related artifacts.Wilson, Frederic Woodbridge. [http://arcadia.org/pml/gs-collection.html The Gilbert and Sullivan Collection] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105164350/http://arcadia.org/pml/gs-collection.html |date=January 5, 2009 }} at The Morgan Library website, accessed May 5, 2010 Of interest to Australians is a copy of the letter written by Andrea Corsali from India in 1516. This letter, one of five in existence, contains the first description of the [[Southern Cross]] which is also illustrated by Corsali in this letter and which was also named "croce" by him. One other copy of the letter is in the British Library and two are in Australia. The fifth is in the Library of Princeton University. The letter is also readily available in Ramusio's ''Viaggi'', a compendium of letters of exploration, published in Venice in three volumes from 1555. == Architecture == [[File:Morgan Library McKim Building from west.jpg|right|thumb|The historic McKim Building]] [[File:Morgan Library McKim Building Edward Clark Potter lions.jpg|thumb|right|[[Edward Clark Potter]]'s lions]] The first building constructed to house Morgan's library – the "McKim Building" – was designed in the [[Classical Revival architecture|Classical Revival style]] by [[Charles Follen McKim]] of the noted firm of [[McKim, Mead & White]] in 1903. Morgan also commissioned a house to be built for his daughter a block away at the same time. It is located at 33 East 36th Street, which was at the time just to the east of Morgan's residence, a brownstone house at 219 Madison Avenue built in 1880. McKim took his inspiration from the [[Villa Giulia]] and its [[Nymphaeum]]. The building was constructed from 1902-1907 and has a facade of [[Tennessee marble]] and a [[Palladian architecture|Palladian arch]] entrance which features two lionesses sculpted by [[Edward Clark Potter]], who would later create the two lions that guard the [[New York Public Library Main Branch|New York Public Library]]'s main building.{{cite inside}}, pp.197-198 Also in the entrance are [[roundels]] and panels by [[Andrew O'Connor (sculptor)|Andrew O'Connor]] and [[Adolph Weinman]]. [[File:Pierpont Morgan Library LOC gsc.5a29820.jpg|thumb|left|Interior in 1963]] [[File:I Morgan Library, New York City, NY, USA 2 (2).jpg|thumb|left|Morgan Library, New York City, NY]] The interior of the building is richly decorated, with a [[polychrome]] rotunda which leads to three public rooms, which were originally Morgan's private study, the librarian's office, and the library itself. The rotunda itself has a domed ceiling with murals and plasterwork inspired by [[Raphael]], created by [[H. Siddons Mowbray]]. Morgan's study, now the West Library, has been called "one of the greatest achievements of American interior decoration," while the East Library features triple-tiers of bookcases. Morgan's residence was torn down in 1928, after his death, to be replaced by an annex building which featured an exhibition hall and a reading room, designed by [[Benjamin Wistar Morris (architect)|Benjamin Wistar Morris]] to harmonize with McKim's original. [[File:I Morgan Library, New York City, NY, USA (2).jpg|thumb|upright|The Italianate brownstone house at Madison Avenue and East 37th Street was built in 1854 by Isaac Newton Phelps and bequeathed to his daughter Helen Stokes, wife of [[Anson Phelps Stokes]].]] The remaining Italianate brownstone house in the library complex is 231 Madison Avenue, on the corner of East 37th Street. This house was built by [[Isaac Newton Phelps]] who bequeathed it to his daughter, Helen Stokes, wife of [[Anson Phelps Stokes]]. She extended the building, doubling the size and adding an additional attic floor (architect [[R. H. Robertson]]). Their son, architect [[Isaac Newton Phelps Stokes]], was born in the house on April 11, 1867. The house was purchased by J. P. Morgan in 1904. It served as the home of his heir J. P. Morgan Jr. from 1905 to 1943.{{cite book|last1=Stokes|first1=Anson Phelps|title=Stokes Records|date=1915|publisher=Privately|page=13|edition=Vol. 3}} === 2006 renovation === [[File:Morgan Library entrance building and library annex.jpg|left|thumb|The [[Renzo Piano]]-designed entrance building (2006, left) and the [[Benjamin Wistar Morris (architect)|Benjamin Wistar Morris]]-designed annex building (1928, right).]] The most recent addition to the library is a modernist entrance building designed by Italian architect [[Renzo Piano]] – his New York City debut – and [[Beyer Blinder Belle]], which was completed in 2006. Although externally "bland", the building helps to organize the interior spaces of the complex. The Library was closed during the construction and expansion. In the interim it sponsored numerous traveling exhibitions around the country. When the work was completed, it reopened on April 29, 2006 as the Morgan Library & Museum. With the expansion above and below street level, the Morgan's exhibition space had been doubled; Piano set its new reading room under a translucent roof structure, to allow scholars to examine manuscripts in natural light. Piano's four-story steel-and-glass atrium links McKim's library building and the Morgan house in a new ensemble. Added storage facilities were obtained by drilling into [[Manhattan schist|Manhattan's bedrock schist]]. ==Management== Between 1987 and 2008, Charles E. Pierce Jr. served as director of what was then known as the Pierpont Morgan Library.Carol Vogel (May 20, 2015), [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/21/arts/design/cleveland-museum-of-art-names-william-m-griswold-director.html] ''[[New York Times]]''. During his tenure at the Morgan Library and Museum between 2008 and 2015, director William M. Griswold spearheaded the growth of its collections, exhibition programs and curatorial departments, adding a photography curator in 2013, a first for the institution. In an effort to reach a younger audience, he also presented many contemporary-art exhibitions and installed temporary sculpture in its atrium.Carol Vogel (May 20, 2015), [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/21/arts/design/cleveland-museum-of-art-names-william-m-griswold-director.html Cleveland Hires Leader of Morgan] ''[[New York Times]]''. In 2015, the Morgan named [[Colin Bailey (museum director)|Colin Bailey]] as its new director.Pac Pobric (April 17, 2015), [http://theartnewspaper.com/news/museums/154428/ Colin Bailey named head of the Morgan Library and Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418222726/http://theartnewspaper.com/news/museums/154428/ |date=April 18, 2015 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''. == References == '''Notes''' {{Reflist|2}} '''Further reading''' * {{Cite book | author = [[John Pierpont Morgan|Morgan, John Pierpont]] | url = https://archive.org/details/checklistofcopti00pier | title = List Of Coptic Manuscripts In The Pierpont Morgan Library | location = New York | publisher = privately printed | year = 1919}} * Voelkle, William [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9403EEDD1439F93BA25754C0A964948260 "Morgan Mansion" (letter to the editor)] ''[[The New York Times]]'', (July 18, 1982) == External links == {{Spoken Wikipedia|Wikipedia_Audio_-_Morgan Library & Museum.wav|2018-11-03}} * {{Commons category-inline}} * {{Official website|http://www.themorgan.org/ }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050830080608/http://www.stbernards.org/newslet/no27_p24.html St. Benard's Obit for Frederick Baldwin Adams Jr.] {{New York City Historic Sites}} {{Museums in
